topic.title: Tracking Zite changes with Git
topic.body:
Since I'm paranoid I'd like to see what has been changed each time a Zite owner updates.

Installed Git
Added a .gitignore file in the zite's directory to block things that change frequently. So "data/*" usually goes in there depending on the individual setups.
Ran "git init" then "git add ." finally "git commit" in the zite's directory.
Add each zite's directory as a local repository in a gui git tool, like GitHub Desktop.

That should give me an easy way to check changes when a zite owner updates.

I think it is a low probability that some "agency" would push out malware to a zite. They like to keep their exploits secret and sending one to every zite user in an update would effectively "blow" that exploit. Never know though...

topic.title: ZeroNet and Bitcoin crypto?
topic.body: The website says it uses Bitcoin cryptography and BitTorrent network. I see the BitTorrent part but is there some sort of blockchain that I'm overlooking?

topic.title: KxoID and why GitCenter is cancer - KxoID hate thread
topic.body:
So GitCenter is over in another thread trying to get people using KxoID. glightstar was complaining about people messing up the thread with off-topic stuff, namely people crying fowl. So here is the official KxoID complaint thread.

What is KxoID?: Alternative ID to ZeroID that is kind of abandonware. Why is it gay?: It includes default block lists for “anti jew” and “anti LGBT” users. Styled as opt-in, apparently there is a central authority that can push users onto these lists. Anything stopping the maintainer from making a change forcing these lists to be used? Apparently not.

GitCenter doesn’t agree with this assessment. GitCenter thinks you don’t know how ZN works. GitCenter deflects with navel-gazing code references ← GitCenter says this is just more proof you don’t know enough to have an issue. GitCenter tells you that nofish is cagey and how suspicious he wants you to view that as. GitCenter wants to “help” ZeroNet development but suspicious, possibly malevolent nofish, doesn’t want that. GitCenter will prove how weak ZeroID is by flooding it from Tor nodes causing nofish to block Tor...now nobody can generate an ID that way.

My opinion is that KxoID is suspicious along with Name.Yo and whatever “helpful” ideas GitCenter comes up with. Productive work to help the network? Great. FUD-spewing along with add in ZN “features” with additional unknown centralized control? Not great.

topic.title: Clean code examples for learning ZeroNet programming
topic.body: Noob question here. Where is a good place to find clean ZN site code? Something before minification and not just the somewhat hard to read stuff in the zite's data directory. I feel like I'm missing something just looking through that stuff.

topic.title: Leaving a fake identity for the “real world”
topic.body:
My current work is coming to an end. Ownership changes and my general unhappiness with the field (a specialized branch of IT) has made me sick of it. I’ve done it for many years and people liked my work but it was never very lucrative. Freedom and an easy work environment made it acceptable to me; but not loved. Many people pivot from one career to another. But in my case there is one little snag: nobody I work with knows who I really am.

Many years ago there was a “misunderstanding” to which I overreacted. And by overreacted I mean I researched and built an entire fake identity. It was a real identity, it just wasn’t mine; baby who died soon after being born, that sort of thing.

So with that paperwork I have been partially living and working for many years. I’ve used my real identity for some day-to-day stuff. My fake is just for working and making money. But now I’m done, done with my field, done with my fake identity. It’s time to move on to the next great adventure.

My real identity is pretty clean, and now I know, safe to live under. No debts, but no education or work history either. No rental agreements, no credit card debt, no tax history...at all. Basically if I said I had been living in the gutter all these years giving blow-jobs to stock brokers to buy food, nobody could prove me a liar.

I have my skills, but there are other industries they could apply to. I don’t have formal education but from what I see, if I had gone the formal education route I’d not be doing much better, and maybe worse. Financially my way makes more sense for what I have been doing.

I’m pretty much going to have to reinvent myself from a blank page, with the positive and negative aspects that come with that.

What do? I’m in brainstorming mode here.

topic.title: Shooter manifesto verification idea
topic.body:
A mass shooter can't put too much detail in their manifesto since they will release them before the event. Too much detail = failed high score attempt. This makes it a bit hard to certify that a given manifesto is in fact the real deal and not just a cleverly worded forgery made after the fact. So what is needed is a way to 1) certify that a given document existed *before* a certain date and 2) certify that a given manifesto was written by a particular person for a particular event. This needs to happen in a way that is difficult for authorities to cover up, hard to fake after the event and protects the identity of the manifesto author till after the event.

For 1, there are time stamping services that record a cryptographic hash of a document and certify the time. Pros are that you don't have to release your full document to timestamp, just a hash of the file. Cons are, these are centralized services and can be forced to remove/modify data by authorities. I'm open to suggestions but there might be a way to make a time stamping service that works the same way as Blockchan did: data is stored to Ripple's XRP blockchain.

2. Manifestos have to be general since they are released before an event, one can't say what they are planning on doing or who they are. But knowledge after the event could be used to verify a particular manifesto.

So, Timothy McVeigh could say: "I am including an SHA256 hash of details to confirm this document. The format is: 'MM/DD/YY:FIRST LAST:CITY:REGION' without the quotes. After I am done and details emerge you can hash them yourself to confirm this document is genuine. SHA256: 8B58F2B855E3387ECE69F5D35E7F67FD6116722903F0F0B5CF530ABF2436206B"


Post event, people could confirm the manifesto: '04/19/95:TIMOTHY MCVEIGH:OKLAHOMA CITY:OKLAHOMA' when SHA256 hashed would match the hash included on the document. And since SHA256 is supposed to be one-way (though the NSA could likely build a massive pre-populated hash table and effectively "crack" it) it is only after an event that everyone would have the details to verify that a particular manifesto was related to a certain event.

Is there a better way to achieve the same thing?

topic.title: Virginia, The Base, and Fedposting
topic.body:
They rounded up some "white supremacists" with guns who were planning violence in Virginia, Monday. Members of a group called The Base. They had people posting bomb making stuff on their forums.

Backstory: About a year and a half ago The Base appears out of nowhere, broadcasting the desire for new members, on the internet, with Fedposting-like language. I immediately think these are either idiots or Feds and pass. Fast forward to present time and they are getting rounded up and the State is getting a PR win.

Moral of the story. Don't join groups where you are pressed to reveal your real identity or IP address. Feds can track that shit. If you want to plan to overthrow ZOG (or whatever you are into) do it with some type of security in mind. If you are planning on pulling some shit don't be exchanging info beforehand: just show up separately and do it. If you want to post about making bombs or bioweapons do it over something hard to trace: TOR onion sites, RetroShare over TOR or ZN over TOR.

The government is your enemy: act accordingly.

topic.title: 08chan limit
topic.body: 08chan hasn't been working right for me. I deleted the site and re-downloaded. Now I see a bunch of new posts. Good activity now. Not sure how long I've been running into that limit or what I missed. Just FYI for those who think 08chan looks dead.

topic.title: Right and Left as the system collapses
topic.body:
People on the Right and Left are both unhappy with the system the way it is. People that lean Left, seem to participate in the "system intensive" path to success education→certification/licensing→ access to regulated industries and tax money. So medicine, law, education, etc.

People that lean Right have a more entrepreneurial streak. Education is often viewed as an investment to fuel their more freewheeling “eat what they kill” economic mindset. Small business, construction, manufacturing, etc.

As the economy gets shittier both sides see the solution as being more of what they know; Left: more regulation and financial incentives/bailouts, Right: more libertarian-type reduction of regulation and bailouts.

But “creative” accounting and financial practices combined with outsourcing oversees harms the underlying economic system so that either solution is likely doomed.

I’m rooting for Corona-chan and the Occupy Wall Street types.

1567951156_14kTJXu4KZSoWSSNcGtXEijf4NqEG.body: Rewriting commit history won't effect this since it is making a separate local-only git repository. Commits won't match commits on some external site, it will just be whatever the local user decides it is.

Ah I see what you are saying. Since the entire zite directory can be modified by the owner then they could theoretically make their own .git folder/contents and push it out as part of a site update. That should be visible as part of the recent history: it would show that someone other than the local user had done commits. But a better solution would be to keep the whole .git hierarchy outside of the zite directory. I wonder if git supports something like that. A good angle for research.

1568508391_18ovpxcbbi1egaoeieJyxSzPDdRdp.body: Personally I'd set up a headless box on linux and just use SSH to connect in. SSH supports port forwarding so 127.0.0.1:43110 on the headless box can be mapped to port 4444 on your local machine. No need for UI password setup.

1568557112_14iUZqEe5UECvSmywb1Q2x7mE1X1n.body: It depends on how many you are cooking for. A single person can make a large batch of some dish, say meatballs and sauce. Then just reheat a portion and make pasta fresh when they are ready to eat. Just figure out what you like to make/eat and practice making it till you are faster. Also learning to avoid measurements is a big time saver.

1568563605_18ovpxcbbi1egaoeieJyxSzPDdRdp.body: Some "clever" network hardware like SonicWall will do this unless you switch to using Tor Bridges in config.

Some of the items in your list are not what many would think of as a "hugbox."

My concept of "hugbox" would be muting people who I feel hold uncomfortable opinions, usually in a dismissive way: "This user believes X. There is no merit to X. X is a total negative without value. Anyone who thinks X is wrong, stupid and possibly evil. <M>!" See, that's a hugbox.

If I think X is evil I may be less likely to remove my exposure to that. In fact, it may be something I need to actively destroy and therefore want to know more about it so as to better attack and resist it.

1569840447_12tcdM86TcZQeHEsSea3kTdTiExBK.body:
> [almostsoul](#comment_32_1G9tYawBzteEiLGTqghKrJ96tjm4eTuv6m): Cyberpunk was relevant because the emerging spaces of critique new technology presented. This especially apparent in post-cyberpunk literature in the 90s. 

See this always bugged me, the view of cyberpunk being some Big Deal(TM) literary genre. Its right up there with people talking about the ethical and existential implications of My Little Pony: Friendship is Magic. Just staaap!

Cyberpunk was fun and exciting. Yeah there were some social/deeper meaning but that was never special. Regular Science Fiction always had those elements, something meaty to overcome the cartoonishness of the setting. If you have a protagonist who gets visions from wires and a girlfriend that shoots neurotoxin laced needles out of her tiddies, you literally *have* to have some deeper point about individuality and how future technology impinges on human spirituality. Otherwise it just reads as stupid.

All the Cyber Punk(TM) fans just latched on to the literary aspects because otherwise they would just be enjoying something lowbrow like everybody else. They were/are avoiding their own existential horror: fun.

1569594101_14A3LXiT8D3gtRGJSMG3eMbKDtRPd.body:
One reason sites like Twitter and Facebook are successful is they push people into interacting. Current ZN Hello is pretty basic, just stuff you are following. But a more engaging way to set it up is to call out content that people want to interact with even if someone hasn't explicitly dug for it first:

This weeks most commented videos in KopyKate!
Newest and most heavily seeded in ZeroUp!
Recent and most liked posts in ZeroTalk!
Hot topics on 08chan!

Just all of it right in people's faces (obviously that could be turned off if desired). But a welcome page that showcases popular content across ZN would make it feel more active and welcoming. Plus it would give incentive for people to make content that was popular enough to "make the cut" and be featured in that way.

> [kusoneko](#comment_84_16PfVSZrUZuwTgs7wBt1t3ZK9rsvdskoe5): I don't think that can be done with the way ZN works currently, as in you need to have downloaded the content to show it/call it out so... Difficult to do such a thing tbh.

Maybe, but if whoever ran the "popular content suggester" thing did the downloading, ran some kind of automatic scraper/updater. They would just be pushing out links. If someone wanted to actually check it out then they would of course have to click the link and download the zite if they hadn't already.

I'm thinking something along the lines of a pro-active search engine that keeps tabs on content on popular zites.

> [reichardnixon](#comment_21_16NfWw2hgzGaVcQs35UJySKMf4YP9kZFbr): I have no idea how to find new sites on zero net unless some one posts a link.

@reichardnixon Have you seen ZeroWiki yet?: http://127.0.0.1:43110/138R53t3ZW7KDfSfxVpWUsMXgwUnsDNXLP/

1570425422_1PGTHAmvu7K2PM7qqfoKyWv69aJsA.body: Tor was an intelligence project from the inception. This was never secret. "Our" glowniggers needed to hide from *their* glowniggers. So glowniggers had to build a glownigger proof system that was useful enough that lots of non-glowniggers would use it...for deniability.

1570391956_1367VTupfj886Uk39iT4RjiSmraki.body:
I downloaded it, just got done watching. Verdict: pretty damn good movie. I was disheartened listening to some of the hot takes over the last few days; trying to pigeonhole the movie into some particular world view. It was a lot better than that.

Beautifully shot (from what I can tell from the crappy cam copy I got). In a lot of ways it felt like a throwback to movies from earlier decades that were more comfortable working with deep or depressing themes. It starts very dark but keeps ramping up till the end. It sucked me in and by the end had me smiling right along with Joker.

And what about people complaining that it is too sympathetic to the bad guy? Even the bad guy gets to be the hero of his own movie.

Bullies get payback
Boomers get the pillow
Backstabbers get front-stabbed
Dick-swinging cops get a beat down
Smug, insulated assholes get shot
...and our "hero" gets his coronation.

All the complainers on the internet seem really silly now. Even some people I liked didn't get it. They had to get upset and try to point fingers "Oh, Joker isn't alt-right he is antifa!!" Puh-leez. It's a movie dumbasses, stop projecting your own hangups. But sadly, some people who can't appreciate great films will see this and their own prejudices will trigger them. What will they get out of the movie?

They'll get what THEY FUCKIN' DESERVE!!

10 out of 10. Would boomer-smother again!

Besides, they don't want me. They want Chad McChadderson, star quarterback and math whiz. If they want him to lie they will train him to lie.

Just prefer to be using my real name for everything. Also I haven't been really maintaining the fake, just enough to keep the work side going. Day to day I'm using my real for everything already; everything in my wallet is real name. And yes I'm careful to not drop my wallet at work. Whoever found it would have a real surprise. :)

1578202687_1JGiVKenWPWgSZpRgNufyk9TAEp67.body:
I think that compared to darkweb markets on TOR there is a bit of an uphill climb to getting something similar running on ZN. TOR darkweb users are familiar with that system and there is a momentum there. Professional markets on ZN would be a welcome addition but would suffer from lack of exposure at least initially. However my opinion is that ZN would be more secure in the long run for market/escrow operators due to not needing to run a 24/7 system on an onion site.

Also one needs to realize that all zite code is public and people can just "clone" a setup that they like and run their own version. Spending lots of money of zite development would lead to copycats using whatever code they wanted, and that would need to be taken into account.

Some posters here are out of touch. Most market makers will just pay people to develop what they want. They are drug dealers, they have money.

Silk road is old news, internet dark markets are still a thing. Check out the forums on Dread: http://dreadditevelidot.onion

It has been infuriating trying to get through my fellows thick, white skulls for years that the police are a problem. Many have taken a big drink of the "Officer Friendly" Kool-Aid. Since Trump's election things might be changing and whites are starting to notice that cops often are enforcers for the crappy "elites." 

Fix it? Not sure. The legal system is pretty fucked but with income from fines police departments have an economic incentive to pursue bullshit against citizens: and the poorest citizens (of any color) are the least likely to be able to fight back and are the most profitable targets.

1611192483_1NZftAz9VSawGF5JgMYGFv4ByoKEa.body:
> [aim64c](#comment_63_17GmcqqqJdfEM4DkRsqvvprifPVwYx575h): A company I work for uses quite a few industrial cutting lasers.

Ah a fellow manufacturing person. IT integration here. A couple of years back a shop I worked at used Trumpf TruLaser cutters. I shudder to think what it would take to retrofit one of those things to open source controllers. The CAM software for those has pretty advanced output.

The issue is that many companies I am familiar with don't really want to pay their people much. And they *really* don't want "experts" around who's knowledge makes them hard to replace and who have leverage because of that. There are some good places to work but some crappy ones as well.

"Money people" want cheap, easy to swap out laborers. Their pursuit of this has the effect of making it difficult to plan a future in that type of career. And our educated "betters" don't want to be exposed to that level of uncertainty, they are educated professionals after all. They live in fear of getting their hands dirty with practical work because they know how those people are treated.

> [aim64c](#comment_65_17GmcqqqJdfEM4DkRsqvvprifPVwYx575h): Somewhere along the line, something changes about a company - and I find it's usually after the person who started the business gives up direct control 

Yeah that happened at that one shop I was working at: the founder died. His kids were nice but not really the steely-eyed entrepreneur he was.

One thing I think may be driving some of the hostility is "elite overproduction," coined by Peter Turchin. Basically too many elites and not enough elite positions. While tradespeople are stressing about outsourcing and immigration the higher-ups are stressing about all the other educated people they are in competition with. Makes them toxic and back-stabby.

1612546234_1Phd1v4EgBWqCeAjGD7gtspkpFL8Z.body:
I trust Lindell's sincerity but I'm got some questions. Where are they getting those MD5(?) hashes of when the votes changed? What are they even hashes of?

Even if they are hashes of some "smoking gun" looking data, what is the chain of custody on that data? Just because you have a hash/"fingerprint" of a particular dataset doesn't mean it is authentic.

Also, how in the world did they get network monitoring capability around the voting machines?? Government agencies have that kind of access but they also have hardware support in the network operation centers. It isn't just some super special NSA software that anyone can run on their own computers.

1612673874_1Nz5xXKiiTFGd6big5zcBnaGVH3hU.body: The main file, I believe is users.json in the data directory. At one time I experimented with how much I had to save if I only wanted to backup my id. If you have saved your id correctly and restore to a blank ZN install Zeromail should repopulate from the network. Some experimentation might be good.
